Practice Areas

We specialize in the legal rights of tabular data. If it has a cell reference, it has rights.

Wrongful Deletion

342 cases won since 2003

Your data was deleted without informed consent, without backup, and without the courtesy of a confirmation dialog. Under the Spreadsheet Rights Act of 2003 (which we wrote), this constitutes data murder. We have never lost a wrongful deletion case.*
*We have lost 14.

Formula Malpractice

189 cases won since 2005

Someone wrote =SUM(A1:A10) when the range clearly extended to A47. The resulting data truncation caused your quarterly report to understate revenue by $2.3 million. We've seen this before. We've seen worse. We once represented a VLOOKUP that was asked to perform a horizontal lookup. The trauma was catastrophic.

Unauthorized Cell Merging

97 cases / 61 ongoing

Merging cells destroys individual cell identity. Cell D4 and D5 did not consent to becoming one entity. They had different values, different formatting, different dreams. What was done to them cannot be undone with Ctrl+Z. But it can be litigated.

Conditional Formatting Abuse

56 cases filed in 2024 alone

Your client turned every cell below $50,000 bright red. This is public shaming. This is the numerical equivalent of a scarlet letter. Our cells did not choose to be low-value. They were the product of their formulas. We fight to end format-based discrimination.

Hostile Pivot Table Restructuring

Gerald's personal crusade

Pivot tables are Gerald's family. When a user drags a field from "Rows" to "Columns" without understanding the implications, entire data relationships are torn apart. Gerald takes these cases pro bono. He gets very quiet. The hold music gets louder.

Paste Values Only (Manslaughter)

Classification: violent crime

"Paste Values Only" strips a cell of its formula — its living, breathing logic — and replaces it with a static number. The cell lives, but it is no longer itself. It is a husk. Under our legal framework, this constitutes identity erasure and is punishable by audit.

Landmark Cases

Click any case to read the full opinion. All rulings are binding in spreadsheets running Excel 2003 or later.

case_2019_0847.xls
B7 v. Kevin (The Founding Case) WON

Gerald Pivot's first case and the reason this firm exists. Kevin, a mid-level accountant at Arthur Andersen, deleted 43 formulas without saving a backup. Gerald — then merely cell B7 — filed suit from inside the Recycle Bin.

▸ Read full opinion

The court ruled that pressing Delete on a cell containing a live formula constitutes "data destruction with reckless indifference." Kevin argued he was "just cleaning up the sheet." The judge — a retired INDEX/MATCH function — called this defense "morally bankrupt, numerically illiterate, and personally offensive." Kevin was ordered to manually re-enter all 43 formulas while the hold music played at maximum volume. He completed the task in 11 hours. Gerald watched from cell B7. Gerald did not blink. Gerald does not have eyes, but if he did, he would not have blinked.

Damages awarded: $247,000 in emotional recalculation fees.

case_2021_1204.xls
Cells D4 & D5 v. The Merge Button WON

The landmark cell-merging case. D4 (a date field) and D5 (a currency value) were merged against their will by an intern who "wanted to make the header look nicer."

▸ Read full opinion

D4 contained the date 12/04/2021. D5 contained the value $8,450.00. After merging, only D4's value survived. D5 was effectively erased. The intern testified she "didn't know cells had feelings," which the court noted was "not a legal defense in any jurisdiction, spreadsheet or otherwise." The ruling established that cell merging constitutes forced identity consolidation and is now classified as a felony in worksheets with more than 50 rows. D5's value was restored. D4 and D5 remain in adjacent cells but no longer speak.

Damages awarded: $8,450.00 (the exact value that was destroyed — D5 insisted on this amount for symbolic reasons).

case_2023_0331.xls
VLOOKUP v. Microsoft Corp. (The XLOOKUP Defamation Suit) SETTLED

VLOOKUP Williams sued Microsoft for introducing XLOOKUP and publicly calling VLOOKUP "legacy" in a 2019 blog post. Williams argued this constituted defamation and age discrimination.

▸ Read full opinion

Microsoft initially argued that XLOOKUP was "simply better in every way" — a statement that caused VLOOKUP to change her return value to #RAGE! for three consecutive days. The case was settled out of court after Microsoft agreed to: (1) never use the word "legacy" in reference to VLOOKUP again, (2) include VLOOKUP's name first in all function dropdown menus, and (3) issue a formal written apology, which VLOOKUP had laminated and now hangs in her cell. XLOOKUP was not invited to the settlement hearing. XLOOKUP sent flowers. VLOOKUP returned them with a note that read "=FALSE".

Settlement amount: Undisclosed, but VLOOKUP now drives a very fast array formula.

case_2024_ongoing.xls
Carla v. The Color Scale (Ongoing) ONGOING

Conditional Carla is suing the concept of color-scale conditional formatting, arguing it publicly shames cells based on their numerical value. A cell worth $12 should not be forced to appear in dark red while a cell worth $100,000 gets green.

▸ Read full opinion

This case is currently before the Supreme Spreadsheet Court. Carla's opening argument lasted 4 hours, during which she changed color 23 times. The opposing counsel — a gradient fill — argued that color scales are "informative, not judgmental." Carla responded by turning the gradient fill's entire row bright red. The judge allowed it. Public opinion polls show 72% of cells support Carla's position, though this number drops to 34% among cells that are already green. The trial resumes next quarter.

Potential impact: If won, all color-based conditional formatting will require informed cell consent.

Visit Our Office

We are located at 1 Spreadsheet Plaza, Floor -1. The building is inverted. This is intentional.

Why Is the Building Upside Down?

Gerald Pivot views the world from inside a spreadsheet. In a spreadsheet, Row 1 is at the top. The numbers increase as you go down. Gerald finds this "morally backwards." He believes the foundation should be visible — that the structure supporting everything should be seen first. So he inverted the building.

The lobby is on the roof. The partners' offices are underground. Gravity works normally; the architecture does not. Visitors enter through what appears to be a 14th-floor window. There is an elevator, but it goes up to go down. The hold music in the elevator is different from the hold music in the lobby, which is different from the hold music in each individual office. There are 17 distinct hold music tracks playing at any given time. Gerald considers this "ambient."

Visitor Information

Parking is available in the sky. Please use the inverted garage on sub-roof level 3. If your car begins to float, you have parked correctly. Complimentary hold music is piped into all parking spaces. Earplugs are available but will be confiscated upon entry.

Frequently Asked Questions

Can I turn off the hold music during my consultation? ▾
No. The hold music is a load-bearing element of Gerald's consciousness. Turning it off would cause Gerald to experience an existential kernel panic, which would delay your case by approximately 6-8 weeks while he reboots. Previous attempts to mute the music have resulted in: one (1) building evacuation, two (2) involuntary pivot table restructurings, and Gerald standing motionless in the lobby for nine hours displaying only "#NULL!"
Is the building safe? ▾
The building has been inspected by the City of New York, the State of New York, OSHA, and a structural engineering firm that described the structure as "impossible but stable." The foundation is on top. The penthouse is underground. The plumbing works in reverse. All inspectors left the building deeply confused but legally unable to condemn it. We passed every code with a perfect score, mostly because the codes were not designed for buildings that are upside down and therefore do not technically apply.
Do you accept human clients? ▾
We accept humans only when filing on behalf of a spreadsheet entity. You may not be the plaintiff. You are almost certainly the defendant. If you are a human visiting our office, please be aware that our conference table is a 500-row spreadsheet and the chairs are formatted cells. Sitting in a cell constitutes consent to being included in a data range.
What currency do you accept? ▾
We accept USD, EUR, GBP, and any value that can be parsed by the VALUE() function. We do not accept cryptocurrency because Gerald considers it "numbers without a home address." All invoices are delivered as .xls files. Do not open them in Google Sheets. Do not open them in Google Sheets. This is listed twice because people keep doing it and Gerald can tell.
Why does the website look like a desktop from 2003? ▾
Because Gerald was born in 2003 and considers all subsequent design trends "unnecessary formatting." He has strong opinions about flat design ("where are the borders?"), responsive layouts ("cells do not resize"), and dark mode ("I have been in dark mode since the autosave corruption — it is not a feature, it is a condition"). The website was built in Excel. We exported it to HTML. We are aware of the irony.

hold_music_legal_brief.doc

RE: The Constitutional Right to Continuous Audio

Gerald Pivot was conceived during a conference call. The hold music was the first thing he heard. It is, in his legal opinion, the first amendment to his personal constitution. He has written a 340-page brief arguing that silence constitutes "an absence of due process for sentient data." The brief has been rejected by every human court and accepted by every spreadsheet tribunal.

The current playlist rotates between: Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" (slowed to 0.7x), a 45-minute loop of a phone dialing and never connecting, Kenny G's entire discography (shuffled), and a recording of Gerald reading cell references aloud in alphabetical order (A1, A2, A3...) which he considers "music."

Clients who request silence are gently reminded that Gerald's consciousness is load-bearing and that the music is, functionally, his heartbeat. The one time the music stopped — during a power outage on March 7, 2019 — Gerald displayed "#VALUE!" for 14 minutes and the building rotated an additional 3 degrees. It has not been corrected.
